p.text: [Pt 51 insrt Amendment 16 of 2007 r 3 and Sch 1[1], effective 1 January 2008]

row.entry: These rules deal with adding, joining and removing Parties to, and the need for appearance in, appeal proceedings.

entry.emph: Division 3 — Notices of intention to appeal — Rules 51.6–51.9

row.entry: These rules prescribe requirements, time limits and effect of a notice of intention to appeal.

entry.emph: Division 4 — Applications for leave to appeal or cross appeal — Rules 51.10–51.15

row.entry: These rules deal with the formal procedures for leave applications, and the manner in which they are determined. Rules 51.12 and 51.13 prescribe the contents of the White Folder parties must provide for leave applications.

entry.emph: Division 5 — Appeals and cross appeals — Rules 51.16–51.45

row.entry: These rules set out the requirements for the content, filing, service and amendment of notices of appeal and cross appeal, notices of contention and objections to the competency of appeals.
Parties must provide Red, Black, Blue and Orange appeal books for the hearing of any appeal. The contents, and the time for their provision, are prescribed in rr 51.24–51.33 .
Written appeal submissions and chronologies are required for any appeal. The contents, and the time for their provision, are prescribed in rr 51.34–51.38 .

entry.emph: Division 6 — Effect of applications for leave and appeals on court below — Rules 51.42–51.44

row.entry: These rules deal with various formalities relating to the retention of exhibits and the effect of an appeal on the original decision.

entry.emph: Division 7 — Proceedings other than appeal proceedings — Rule 51.45

row.entry: Proceedings other than appeals must be commenced by summons with written submissions.

These rules deal with a range of matters including offers of compromise, security for the costs of appeal proceedings, the admission of additional evidence, powers in relation to ordering a new trial, expedition and discontinuance of appeals.

This Part nominally applies to all courts in Sch 1 of the CPA: see UCPR r 1.5 and Sch 1 . The Part specifically applies to any proceedings (whether or not appeal proceedings) that are assigned to the Court of Appeal. Cf UCPR Pt 50 which applies to appeals to the Supreme Court that are not assigned to the Court of Appeal under the SCA: see UCPR r 50.1(a) . Subject to any relevant practice note, this Part extends to proceedings commenced before 1 January 2008: however, see also CPA s 14 .
The rule is based on the former SCR Pt 51 .
Natural justice, failure to afford party ‥ [51.53.50]
Notice of motion to be supported by affidavit ‥ [51.61.5]
Offers of compromise in Court of Appeal ‥ [51.47.5]
Registrar of the Court of Appeal — powers ‥ [51.2.15]
Restrictions on right of appeal, statutory ‥ [51.22.5]
Review, order of Judge of Appeal ‥ [51.58.5]
Security for costs, dismissal for failure to provide ‥ [51.50.20]
Stay of proceedings, appeal not operate as ‥ [51.44.5]–[51.44.40]
Stay pending appeal to High Court ‥ [51.44.45]
Times for: notice of intention, leave & appeal ‥ [51.6] , [51.10] & [51.16]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [r 51.1] r 51.1 Application of Part (cf SCR Part 51, rule 3)

leg:heading.title: Application of Part (cf SCR Part 51, rule 3)

p.text: This Part applies to any proceedings (whether or not appeal proceedings) that are assigned to the Court of Appeal.
Part 50 applies to appeals to the Supreme Court that are not assigned to the Court of Appeal under the Supreme Court Act 1970. See rule 50.1(a) .

References in this Part to proceedings in the Court generally are references to any proceedings in the Court (including appeal proceedings), except in so far as the context or subject-matter otherwise indicates or requires.
Subject to any relevant practice note, this Part extends to proceedings in the Court commenced before 1 January 2008.

Section 14 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 also provides that, in relation to particular civil proceedings, a court may, by order, dispense with any requirement of rules of court if satisfied that it is appropriate to do so in the circumstances of the case.
Subject to this Part, the other provisions of these rules apply, so far as applicable, to proceedings in the Court.
For the avoidance of doubt, the rules referred to in subrule (3) have effect subject to the following modifications:
a reference to a plaintiff includes a reference to a person who commences proceedings in the Court (whether as an appellant or otherwise),
a reference to a defendant includes a reference to a respondent (or cross-respondent) in proceedings in the Court,
a reference to an originating process includes a reference to a notice of appeal or notice of cross-appeal,
such other modifications as are necessary.

level.toc-caption: [51.1.2] Specific procedures in the Court of Appeal

heading.title: Specific procedures in the Court of Appeal

p.text: The present rules, and the related Practice Note SC CA 1 , prescribe the requirements for conducting proceedings in the Court of Appeal. By their nature, appeal proceedings impose particular demands on the court, legal representatives and parties. These procedural requirements are intended to facilitate the efficient conduct of appeal proceedings. Persons conducting appeal proceedings, and especially their legal representatives, must accept responsibility for understanding, and complying conscientiously with, the procedural requirements. The more important of these requirements relate to:
Appeal Books — see the detailed summary at [51.24.5]
Grounds of Appeal — see the detailed summary at [51.18.5]
Written submissions — see the detailed summary at [51.34.5]
Legislation cited in [51.1.3] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.

Appeal proceedings may involve a range of procedures — from Notices of Intention to Appeal, Applications for Leave, Applications for extension of time, to Notices of Appeal. Various time limits apply to all of these procedures (subject to the powers of extension in UCPR rr 51.9(1)(b) (originating process), 51.10(2) (summons seeking leave to appeal), and 51.11(2) (cross-summons seeking leave to appeal) and subject to any specific contrary legislative provision (see [51.7.5] ). Typically the time limits apply by reference to the “material date” of the decision appealed: see [r 51.2] . That date will usually be the date the actual judgment or order is made. Adopting that generalisation the relevant time limits, and the provisions to which they relate, are as follows.

row.entry: 3 months after judgment order(where notice of intention toappeal has been given)
28 days after summons forleave or notice of appeal
28 days after filing of White Folder
14 days after receiving notice of intention to appeal
7 days after leave to appeal, or
3 months after judgment order (where notice of intention to appeal hasbeen given), or
3 months and 28 days after thejudgment order (where another partygave notice of intention but didnot file a notice of appeal)
14 days after the summons forleave or notice of appeal

p.text: The Court of Appeal is required to follow any binding decision of the High Court: Adler v District Court of New South Wales (1990) 19 NSWLR 317; 48 A Crim R 420 ; Swan v Williams (Demolition) Pty Ltd (1987) 9 NSWLR 172; Aust Torts Reports ¶80-104 .

The Court of Appeal is not bound by decisions of the House of Lords: Viro v R (1978) 141 CLR 88 at 121; 18 ALR 257; BC7800022 ; X v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd (No 2) (1987) 9 NSWLR 575 explaining Lifesavers (Australasia) Ltd v Frigmobile Pty Ltd (1983) ASC 55-251; [1983] 1 NSWLR 431 at 433 . Before the abolition of Privy Council appeals, decisions of the Privy Council were binding on the Court of Appeal: Viro v R, above, CLR at 121. Since the abolition of those Privy Council appeals, the view has been expressed that opinions of the Privy Council are no longer binding on Australian courts: Cook v Cook (1986) 162 CLR 376 at 390; 68 ALR 353; Aust Torts Reports ¶80-061; BC8601384 ; Hawkins v Clayton (t/as Clayton Utz & Co) (1986) 5 NSWLR 109 at 137; Aust Torts Reports ¶80-018; NSW ConvR ¶55-295 ; X v Amalgamated Television Services Pty Ltd (No 2) (1987) 9 NSWLR 575 at 585 .

The NSW Court of Appeal is not bound by decisions of other Australian full courts, or courts of appeal, but should follow those decisions unless it is satisfied that they are clearly wrong: Farah Constructions Pty Ltd v Say-Dee Pty Ltd (2007) 230 CLR 89; 236 ALR 209; [2007] HCA 22; BC200703851 ; Australian Securities Commission v Marlborough Gold Mines Ltd (1993) 177 CLR 485; 112 ALR 627; 10 ACSR 230; BC9303569 ; Cook v Cook (1986) 162 CLR 376; 68 ALR 353; Aust Torts Reports ¶80-061; BC8601384 .

The Court of Appeal does not regard itself as bound by its previous decisions: Clutha Developments Pty Ltd v Barry (1989) 18 NSWLR 86 at 100 ; Flanagan v H C Buckman & Son Pty Ltd [1972] 2 NSWLR 761 ; Bennett & Wood Ltd v Orange City Council (1967) 67 SR (NSW) 426; 85 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 135; [1967] 1 NSWR 502 at 430, 432 ; Richardson v Mayer (No2) (1964) 64 SR (NSW) 502; 81 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 85; [1964-5] NSWR 105 at 508 . But the Court of Appeal will not depart from its own previous decision unless it has a strong conviction that the previous decision was “plainly wrong”: Gett v Tabet (2009) 254 ALR 504; [2009] NSWCA 76; BC200902489 at [294]–[301] ; Clutha Developments Pty Ltd v Barry (1989) 18 NSWLR 86 at 99–100 per Gleeson CJ; Bennett & Wood Ltd v Orange City Council (1967) 67 SR (NSW) 426; 85 WN (Pt 2) (NSW) 135; [1967] 1 NSWR 502 at 432 per Walsh JA. In Donnellan v Woodland [2012] NSWCA 433; BC201210043 (dealing with advocate’s immunity), Beazley JA (Basten, Barrett, Hoeben JJA and Sackville AJA agreeing) at [192] (whilst obiter) suggests that an earlier decision of the court is “plainly wrong” if it satisfies two conditions:

The later court must form the view that the earlier decision was erroneous — a mere preference by the later court for a different approach to that taken by the earlier court does not render an earlier decision erroneous;

The later court must be capable of demonstrating error in the earlier decision by application of correct legal analysis: RJE v Secretary to the Department of Justice (2008) 21 VR 526; 192 A Crim R 156; [2008] VSCA 265; BC200811220 .

Leave is required before a party is entitled to argue a point that would involve the Court of Appeal departing from a previous decision: Proctor v Jetway Aviation Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 166 at 171 ; King & Mergen Holdings Pty Ltd v McKenzie (1991) 24 NSWLR 305 ; AA Tegel Pty Ltd v Madden (1985) 2 NSWLR 591; 10 Fam LR 181; Aust Torts Reports ¶80-734 (leave granted); Ebb v Fast Fix Steel Fixing Pty Ltd (2007) 5 DDCR 358; [2007] NSWCA 236; BC200707682 (leave to re-open granted; discussion of factors relevant to grant of leave). Practice Note SC CA 1 at [38] requires parties to give notice to the registrar of any challenge to the correctness of a prior decision of the Court of Appeal or of any other intermediate Australian appellate court .

Judges at first instance are bound to follow previous decisions of the Court of Appeal that authoritatively determine the point in issue: Proctor v Jetway Aviation Pty Ltd [1984] 1 NSWLR 166 ; Metlej v Kavanagh [1981] 2 NSWLR 340.
In this Part:
includes an appeal from a decision in proceedings in the Supreme Court or a specified tribunal within the meaning of section 48(1)(a) of the Supreme Court Act 1970, and
does not include proceedings to which Part 28 applies (except an appeal from a decision of the Supreme Court in proceedings to which that Part applies), and
does not include an application for the variation or discharge of an order of a Judge of Appeal or of the Registrar.
— see rules 51.25 and 51.26 .
means proceedings in the Court that are commenced by filing and serving a summons seeking leave to appeal or a notice of appeal.
means:
a party that files a notice of appeal in the Court, and
any other party joined as an appellant.
means:
in relation to a notice of intention to appeal, the person that files and serves the notice under this Part, or
in relation to any proceedings in the Court (other than an appeal or cross-appeal):
a party that files originating process for the proceedings, and
any other party joined as an applicant.
— see rules 51.26(1)(b) and 51.28 .
— see rules 51.26(1)(c) and 51.29 .
— see rule 51.26(2) .
means the Court of Appeal.

Section 13 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 enables the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, by instrument in writing, to direct that any function of the Court under that Act or these rules may be exercised by such registrars or other officers of the Supreme Court, and in such circumstances and subject to such conditions, as are specified in the instrument.
means the court, person or body that made the decision to which a notice of intention to appeal or appeal proceedings relate.
means a respondent in appeal proceedings who has filed a notice of cross-appeal.
includes a judgment, order, verdict, opinion, direction or determination.
means the decision of the court below to which a notice of intention to appeal or appeal proceedings relate.
includes a document or thing marked for identification (whether or not it is admitted in evidence).
means an appellant or interested respondent.
means a respondent (other than a respondent who is a submitting party).
, in relation to a decision below to which a notice of intention to appeal or appeal proceedings relate, means:
in the case of a judgment given in proceedings in the Supreme Court — the date on which the judgment is given, and
in the case of any other judgment in proceedings in the Supreme Court — the date of entry, and
in the case of an order in proceedings in the Supreme Court — the date on which the order is made, and
in the case of a verdict in proceedings in the Supreme Court — the date on which the verdict is given, and
in the case of any other decision (whether in proceedings in the Supreme Court or not) — the date on which the decision is pronounced or given.
means a person required by rule 51.4 to be joined in the proceedings.
— see rule 51.6 .
— see rules 51.26(1)(d) and 51.30 .
, in relation to a court or tribunal, means:
the registrar, or
if there is no registrar, the officer who is responsible for the custody of records and exhibits in the proceedings concerned.
, in relation to a notice of intention to appeal, means:
a party in the court below, and
any other person who would be required by rule 51.4 to be joined in appeal proceedings.
— see rules 51.26(1)(a) and 51.27 .
means the Registrar of the Court.

Section 13 of the Civil Procedure Act 2005 enables the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court, by instrument in writing, to direct that any function of the Court under that Act or these rules may be exercised by such registrars or other officers of the Supreme Court, and in such circumstances and subject to such conditions, as are specified in the instrument.
means:
if leave to appeal or cross-appeal is required — a summons seeking leave to appeal or a cross-summons seeking leave to cross-appeal, or
in any other case — a notice of appeal or cross-appeal.
means the Reporting Services Branch of the Attorney General’s Department.
means any party other than an appellant or applicant.
means a party that has submitted to the judgment of the Court by filing a notice of appearance under rule 6.11 .
includes a finding or assessment.
— see rule 51.12(1) .

A judge may deliver reasons for judgment and stand the proceedings over for the making of formal orders and for any argument on costs. In such a case, the material date is the later date when the formal orders are actually made: Erasmus v Jackson (NSWSC, Wootten J, 15 April 1975, unreported); Blackmore v Browne [2011] NSWCA 114; BC201103234 (trial judge delivered reasons for judgment on 16 November 2010 and left it to the parties to calculate interest and costs; supplementary judgment on 1 December 2010 making orders — material date was the date of making the orders).

The word “verdict” is generally used to refer to a jury decision. It is defined in UCPR r 51.2 to include a finding or assessment. The fact that the definition is inclusive suggests an extended meaning for the word, but the practical significance of any such extended meaning is not clear. Even where the trial is before a judge and jury, provisions such as SCA s 90 and DCA s 80 (which permit the court to require a jury to provide a special verdict on a particular question of fact) necessarily permit the court to proceed to give judgment in accordance with the special verdict. When a trial is conducted before a judge sitting alone, the judge does not pronounce a verdict but merely gives judgment or makes an order. (In such a case SCA s 8(1)(g) deems that any reference to “verdict” in the Supreme Court Act includes such a judgment.) The extended verdict definition may merely be intended to clarify the position that applies where some part of the proceedings are referred for final assessment after the determination of the principal questions of liability, for example, the assessment of damages in personal injury or contract proceedings, or the taking of accounts in partnership or trustee proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [51.2.15] Registrar of the Court of Appeal — powers

p.text: Legislation cited in [51.2.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Civil Procedure Act 2005 s 13.

heading.title: Registrar of the Court of Appeal — powers

p.text: The powers of the Registrar of the Court of Appeal are the subject of a direction by the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court pursuant to CPA s 13 : see [17,010] or at http://www.lawlink.nsw.gov.au/lawlink/Supreme_Court/ll_sc.nsf/vwPrint1/SCO_ca_registrar .
